thread.title: WikiLeaks publishes CIA director's personal information
thread.title_full: WikiLeaks publishes CIA director's personal information

author: Kevin Johnson
title: WikiLeaks publishes CIA director's personal information
text:
CIA Director John Brennan. Photo: AP
WikiLeaks published personal information on Thursday allegedly drawn from CIA Director John Brennan's private email account that exposed telephone numbers, home addresses, and passport and social security numbers.
Much of the personal information was contained in an application for a national security clearance dated 2008, well before he was named CIA director.
In a written statement, the CIA immediately condemned the release, characterising the breach as "a crime".
WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been holed up in the Ecuadorian embassy in the UK since 2012 fighting extradition to Sweden in relation to allegations of sexual assault. Photo: Yui Mok/AP
"The hacking of the Brennan family account is a crime and the Brennan family is the victim," the agency said. "The private electronic holdings of the Brennan family were plundered with malicious intent and now being distributed across the web. The attack is something that could happen to anyone and should be condemned, not promoted."
Advertisement The CIA said there was no indication so far that any of the documents exposed are classified.
"The documents released are those that a private citizen with national security interests and expertise would be expected to possess," according to the CIA statement.
The disclosures come after a hacker, described as an American high school student, initially claimed in a New York Post report to have breached the private email accounts of Brennan and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson. Following those claims, the hacker posted separate personal information associated with Brennan, Johnson and other current and former intelligence officials.
None of that material contained classified information, officials said, though the breaches prompted the Secret Service and the FBI to launch an investigation into the attacks.
Among the additional documents disclosed by WikiLeaks included a copy of a US Senate bill outlining certain torture techniques and a draft position paper, titled "The Conundrum of Iran".
The paper was drafted as a briefing document prior to US President Obama's election in 2008.
"Whoever takes up residence at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in January 2009 will need to 'hit the ground running' on Iran, especially since Tehran will react immediately to the new administration's policy statements," the paper stated, adding that the new president should "tone down the rhetoric".
USA Today
